description: Middle English marche; from Anglo-Norman and Old French. Akin to Old English germearc, Gothic marka (“boundary”).

entries.meaning: (historical) An inhabitant of a march (border country); specifically, a marcher lord. [from 14th c.]
(historical) A border territory, a march (now only in (attributive) use). [from 15th c.]
examples: Here is a scene of the marcher state of which they were margraves being turned into a duchy under Henry II Jasomirgott, who has made his capital at Vienna.

entries.meaning: One who marches; one who participates in a march.
